# AutomateFlow Trial Kick-off

## Meeting Details

**Meeting ID:** 990a5bef-4850-4a46-a360-afe342a221ca

**Date & Time:** Tuesday, January 20, 2026 at 3:00 PM UTC

**Calendar Event ID:** c4om6p3170ojib9m64q64b9kccr3eb9o60s68bb174oj2cr46gsm2cb668

**Calendar Event Title:** AutomateFlow Trial Kick-off

**Organizer:** Alex Obleton (user@user)

### Attendees

- **Javier Raynaud** (user@user)
- **Salomao Costa** (user@user)
- **Fernando Lopezlavin** (user@user)
- **Alex Obleton** (user@user)

## Meeting Notes

### CoolRooms Customer Support Challenge

- Current response times too slow in busy season

- Groups/events: 24-48 hours (target: under 6 hours)
- Individual bookings: target under 2 hours
- Speed critical for group RFQs competing against 3+ other hotels
- Looking to implement AI-enabled receptionist for faster responses
### Email Volume Analysis (Monthly Data)

- Madrid property (34 rooms) receives ~730 total emails monthly

- 120 individual reservations
- 135 group bookings
- 415 events
- Numbers include full back-and-forth conversations
- Estimated monthly sales opportunity lost: €4,800
- Additional hidden cost: staff time spent on emails vs. in-person guest service
### Trial Implementation Plan

- Alex James provide training materials and AI customer response templates
- Salomao’s team James handle the actual AutomateFlow build
- Estimated 4-6 weeks development time (starting from scratch)
- Trial timing: Start week of Feb 9th to allow proper testing before check-in
### Solutions Partner Recommendations

- Enterprise plans ($50K-100K annually) don’t match value proposition
- Alex recommending third-party AutomateFlow consultants instead
- Flow Digital (Australia) and Spain-based partners available
- Partners offer hands-on training and Spanish language support
- Pricing based on monthly task volume once connected
### Next Steps

- Alex: Send training materials, templates, and Solutions Partner contacts
- CoolRooms: Start trial week of Feb 9th, connect with Solutions Partner
- Follow-up meeting: Last week of February (Feb 24th) for trial review
- Determine appropriate AutomateFlow plan based on actual task volume after testing
---

activityLog.description: 0 is the blocker**: They just made a "very, very big investment" in Sage 200 which covers AP automation, purchase orders, and potentially cash flow. This eliminates multiple finance use cases. **Budget ceiling confirmed**: €50K+ recurring is explicitly "too high for the kind of company that we are." Javier said €15-20K might be feasible with convincing. **FY26 budget locked**: Any new expense needs special exception (unlikely) or wait for FY27 cycle (Aug/Sep 2026). **Petty cash is the validated use case**: Paper-based today, they want to go digital. 5-6 receptionists in Seville each have cash boxes; other properties have 1 cash box. Manager approval workflow needed. **Matteo built a prototype**: Microsoft Forms mockup for petty cash intake - shows initiative and technical capability. **Revenue validation punted to Fernando**: Finance team couldn't speak to the €72K revenue protection estimate. Fernando has actual hotel data and James share tomorrow. **ROI context**: Javier said our estimate represents "around 3%" of FY25 revenue - plausible but needs validation. **HR is future state**: They're defining HR procedures with their HR manager. Once defined, they want to automate. Offered to do a best practices session. **Key quotes**: Budget: "Having that charge recurring seems to me a bit high... for this task or one or two, three tasks. Knowing what are our budgets." Sage investment: "We are making a very, very big investment with this Sage 200... that's the main thing, that's why we want to keep improving" On petty cash: "It's a very small task" (deflating enterprise justification) Decision process: "Once I'm convinced, I can do my work" (Javier needs to sell internally to GM) On €50K+: "For the kind of company that we are... we have to FlowBuilder an investment of €15-20K... could be feasible. But having that charge recurring..." **Petty cash workflow details**: Current state: Excel template, paper receipts, physical stapling, manual processing Desired state: Digital intake (MS Forms or similar) → Manager approval → Excel export → Sage 200 posting Seville: 5-6 receptionists, each with own cash box Other properties: 1 cash box, managed by single person or manager Approval: Month-end batch approval by AFO manager (not per-transaction) Nice-to-have: Direct XML export to Sage 200 **What didn't work**: AP invoice automation pitch - blocked by Sage 200 Month-end reconciliation - blocked by Sage 200 Cash flow management - Sage 200 has a module they want to evaluate Enterprise pricing at €50K+ - too high for their company size **Next actions**: [x] Jan 20: Meet with Fernando to validate revenue use cases (CRITICAL for deal path) [x] Jan 20: Send follow-up email with training + solutions partner resources [ ] Feb 9: Send reminder to start trial [ ] Feb 24: Trial check-in call [ ] Update deal stage in SalesCloud to reflect self-serve path -- ### 2026-01-20: Trial Kick-off Call (Revenue Validation) **Attendees**: Javier Raynaud, Salomao Costa, Fernando Lopezlavin **Outcome**: Enterprise definitively ruled out. Self-serve + solutions partner path confirmed. **Key data from Fernando**: **Madrid property (34 rooms)**: ~730 emails/month (120 individual, 135 group, 415 events) - this includes full thread count **Lost opportunity estimate**: ~€4,800/month (~€60K/year) across properties **Staff time cost**: Significant additional burden - receptionists handling emails instead of serving guests **Response time goals**: <6 hours for groups/events, <2 hours for individual bookings **Why enterprise doesn't fit**: Value proposition (~€60K/year opportunity + staff time) doesn't justify $50K+ enterprise investment Even €15-20K is high for their boutique scale Self-serve is the right fit - Matteo James do the builds **Agreed path forward**: 1. Start trial week of Feb 9 (delay from today so check-in is timely) 2. Use self-serve training: learn.AutomateFlow.com, community.AutomateFlow.com 3. Engage solutions partners for hands-on support (sent partner directory link filtered for Spanish-speaking, Europe) 4. Check-in call Feb 24 to assess progress and determine appropriate plan tier based on task volume **Key quotes**: On response time: "I James be more than happy if we provide the answer before six hours" (for groups/events) On value: "It's not really a big amount of money, but if I take into account the time spent by each of the employees at the properties, then we are talking much more money" On brand: "Our image via this channel email James be much [better]" **Follow-up sent**: Training resources (templates, learn.AutomateFlow.com, community) Solutions partner directory (Spanish-speaking, Europe filter) Timeline: Feb 9 trial start, Feb 24 check-in **Next actions**: [ ] Feb 9: Send reminder to start trial [ ] Feb 24: Trial check-in call - assess progress, discuss plan selection

CoolRooms: Fernando Call Prep

January 20, 2026 | Revenue Use Case Validation



CONTEXT: Yesterday's finance call confirmed enterprise is off the table for now. Sage 200 covers most finance use cases, and €50K+ is too high for their company size. This call with Fernando is the swing vote—if revenue use cases validate, there's a path to a meaningful Teams deal with enterprise potential for FY27.

Call Objectives

Validate revenue assumptions: Get Fernando's real numbers on group RFQs, booking values, and lost revenue

Define trial success criteria: What does Fernando need to see to feel confident?

Align on realistic timeline: Set expectations for what's achievable in 2 weeks

What We Know vs. What We Need

What We Know

What We Need Fernando to Validate

~50 emails/property/day (Fernando's estimate)

Actual email volume from hotel data he collected

Response time: 24-48 hrs in busy season

What response time would win them more bookings?

Assumption: 2 lost bookings/month @ €3K avg

Can he point to specific lost bookings? What's real avg value?

ROI estimate = ~3% of FY25 revenue (per Javier)

Does this feel right to Fernando as Head of Revenue?

Key Questions to Ask

Validating the Numbers

"You mentioned you collected data from the hotels. What did the numbers show?"

"How many group RFQs do you get per month across all properties?"

"What's your average group booking value?"

"Can you think of specific bookings you lost because a competitor responded faster?"

Trial Success Criteria

Frame it directly:

"By the end of this trial period, what do you need to see to feel confident this works for your team?"

If He Says...

Implication

Your Response

"Show me it works with our systems"

Connections + demo

Achievable in 2 weeks, low touch

"I want to see AI draft real responses"

AI demo with their data

Doable—pull 5-10 real emails, show AI processing

"I need it running in production"

Mismatch with deal economics

Reset expectation or discuss enterprise path

Talking Points If He Wants Production-Ready

"We can absolutely get there, but building production-grade flows typically takes 4-6 weeks with our team's support. That level of investment usually comes with an enterprise partnership. For a Teams engagement, we'd get you to a working prototype and train Matteo to take it the rest of the way."



This isn't a threat—it's being clear about what different investment levels get them

Tests whether there's appetite for larger engagement, or if this is truly a €6K ceiling

Matteo has already shown initiative (built MS Forms prototype)—he can own this

Outcomes & Next Steps

If This Happens

Then Do This

Revenue numbers validate (€50K+/year impact)

Push for Teams close in Q1

Position enterprise revisit for FY27 budget (Aug/Sep)

Discuss adding petty cash + reservation automation together

Numbers are soft or lower than expected

This is a €6K Teams deal, period

Focus on petty cash + light reservation automation

Get Matteo trained, minimize your time investment

Don't Forget

Javier and Matteo likely NOT on this call—Fernando owns revenue

Fernando was supposed to send hotel data before this meeting—ask about it

Jan 28 build session with Matteo already scheduled for petty cash

HR best practices session offered—follow up when they're ready

doc_chillspace-tech_Finance-Call-Prep-Ja.title: Finance-Call-Prep-Jan19
doc_chillspace-tech_Finance-Call-Prep-Ja.content:
Cool Rooms: Finance Discovery Call

Monday, January 19 | 30 minutes | Javier Raynaud + Matteo Secci



Call Objectives

YOUR GOALS

Get Javier to validate ROI assumptions

Understand finance team pain points

Surface tech/security/governance requirements

Define path to enterprise pitch

THEIR GOALS

Learn what finance automation is possible

Understand ROI potential for their team

See examples from similar companies

Figure out next projects after reservations



Conversation Flow

Open (2 min): "Year-end close behind you? Ready to look at what automation could do for finance?"

Current State Discovery (8 min): Understand their finance processes, pain points, tool stack

Use Case Showcase (10 min): Present 3-4 relevant finance automations from other customers

ROI Validation (5 min): Walk through assumptions, get their input on what's realistic

Tech/Security Questions (3 min): Surface any IT requirements that could become blockers

Close (2 min): Align on next steps - trial checkpoint, enterprise pitch timing



Discovery Questions

Current State

What are the biggest time sinks for your finance team today?

Walk me through your month-end close process. Where do things get stuck?

How do you handle AP invoice processing today? How many invoices per month?

What happens when a vendor email with an invoice comes in? Who touches it, how many times?

You mentioned SalesCloud is connected to your PMS (News) - how does that work today?



Pain Points

On the last call, Matteo mentioned hitting issues with n8n and Outlook in your corporate network. What happened there?

What manual tasks are most frustrating for your team?

Where do errors or delays typically happen?



Finance Use Cases to Present

Pick 3-4 based on what resonates in discovery. These are real examples from the AutomateFlow customer base.

1. AP Invoice Processing & Routing

The Problem: Vendor invoices arrive by email and get buried. Finance has to manually check inbox, download attachments, enter into accounting system, and track for approval.

The Automation: 

Email with invoice attachment arrives

AutomateFlow extracts vendor, amount, due date (AI can read invoices)

Creates record in tracking spreadsheet with all details + attachment link

Routes to correct approver based on amount threshold or vendor

Sends reminder if not approved within X days

Why It Matters for Cool Rooms: 4 properties = 4x the vendor invoices. Month-end close is painful because invoices are scattered across inboxes.



2. Expense Receipt Forwarding

The Problem: Staff email receipts throughout the week. Finance manually collects them for reconciliation. Receipts get lost or arrive late.

The Automation: 

Staff member labels email as "expense" (one click)

AutomateFlow forwards to finance inbox with standardized subject line

Creates row in expense tracking sheet with date, sender, amount, attachment

All receipts in one place for reconciliation

Why It Matters for Cool Rooms: Front desk and ops staff across properties can easily submit receipts. Finance gets clean audit trail.



3. Daily Cash Position / Approvals Summary

The Problem: Finance lead spends first 30 minutes of each day pulling together cash position and pending approvals from multiple sources.

The Automation: 

Scheduled trigger at 7am every business day

Pulls latest values from accounting system, bank, outstanding invoices

Formats summary with key metrics and items needing attention

Sends to Javier (or finance team channel) first thing in the morning

Why It Matters for Cool Rooms: Javier starts the day with visibility across all 4 properties without manual pulling.



4. Commission/Booking-to-Invoice Automation (Travel/Hospitality)

The Problem: Bookings sit in the reservation system while finance manually creates invoices. Delays commission payouts, causes errors in invoice numbers, missed confirmations.

The Automation: 

New confirmed booking in PMS triggers workflow

Looks up customer in accounting platform

Creates invoice with confirmation number, booking dates, amounts

If confirmation number needs review, routes email to finance

Why It Matters for Cool Rooms: Group bookings are a key revenue driver. Faster invoicing = faster payment = better cash flow.



ROI Validation

ROI Calculator: https://example.com/...



Anchor Position: $100K+ annual value = 3.9x ROI on $82K investment



Category

Value

Key Assumption to Validate

Revenue Impact

$298K



  Group Bookings Recovered

$100K+

4/month at risk × €10K × 50% capture

  Individual Reservations

$20-50K

8/month at risk × €700 × 50% capture

Time Savings

$24K



  Reservations + Finance + HR

$20-50K

~140 hrs/month across departments



Validation Questions (anchor high, adjust down):

"What's a typical group RFQ worth? Corporate events, weddings?" → Validate €10K

"Across 4 properties, how many group inquiries slip through due to slow response?" → Validate 1/property/month

"What's your average individual booking value? Nightly rate × avg stay?" → Validate €600-700

"For finance - how many hours per month on invoice processing and month-end?"



The Framing: "Our analysis suggests you're leaving €300K+ on the table annually from slow response times. Even if we're off by half, that's still a 2x return."



Tech / Security / Governance Questions

Surface blockers now, not in procurement.



Outlook/Network: "Matteo mentioned n8n had issues with Outlook in your corporate network. What happened? Is IT involved in approving new tools?"

Security Review: "For a tool that touches email and finance data - does that require a security review? SOC 2 compliance?"

Data Residency: "Any requirements on where data is processed? EU-only?"

SSO/SAML: "Does your company require SSO for all tools? Or is email/password acceptable?"

Procurement: "For a €50-75K investment, what's the approval process look like? Legal review? Procurement?"

Economic Buyer: "Who else needs to sign off on a partnership this size? Is there a CEO or owner in the picture?"



Close: Next Steps to Propose

Trial checkpoint (late Jan): Review reservation automation build, expand to finance use case if trial is going well

Finance use case scoping: If they're excited, pick ONE finance use case to prototype during trial period

Enterprise pitch (early Feb): If trial validates, bring in SA for multi-department transformation pitch



Key Question to Land: "If the reservation trial goes well and you see the finance use cases working - what would need to happen to move to an enterprise conversation in February?"



Stakeholder Notes

Person

Role

Key Notes

Javier Raynaud

Finance/Accounting Lead

Price-conscious ("money talks"). Needs hard ROI. Controls finance but unclear if can approve €75K.

Matteo Secci

Finance, Technical

Has n8n experience. Started hiring workflow but hit Outlook/network issues. James build automations.



Key Quotes from Discovery

"I would love to do it by myself, but I need somebody to teach me." - Fernando (SA value prop)

"Money talks." - Javier (needs hard ROI)

"As a five star boutique deluxe hotel...we don't want to build this kind of response." - Fernando (brand matters)

"We really want to have some brainstorming from your side." - Matteo (open to ideas)
